key_points: Facebook shut down accounts of Ugandan government officials ahead of elections.
The shutdown was due to accusations of seeking to manipulate public debate.
Uganda is holding presidential and parliamentary elections, with President Museveni facing Bobi Wine.
Facebook cited 'Coordinated Inauthentic Behaviour' for the account removals.
The network was linked to Uganda's ministry of information and communications technology.
Senior press secretary to President Museveni, Don Wanyama, accused Facebook of influencing the election.
Facebook's action targeted both Facebook and Instagram accounts of officials and ruling party supporters.
Museveni has accused foreign elements of backing his opponent, Bobi Wine.
Over 100 networks have been removed by Facebook since 2017 for similar reasons.
Social media platforms are facing scrutiny for their content management, especially after recent actions against former US President Donald Trump.
spokespersons: Kezia Anim-Addo (Head of Communication, Facebook Sub-Saharan Africa)
Don Wanyama (Senior Press Secretary, President Museveni)
